```{r mwdet, eval=FALSE, include=FALSE}
csvlines <- readLines("cpN1N9.csv")
# We need to select the lines between "Bands:" and "Concentration:"
bands <- grep("Bands:", csvlines, fixed=TRUE, value=FALSE) + 2
conc <- grep("^Concentration:", csvlines, fixed=FALSE,
             value=FALSE) - 3
geldata <- read.delim(header=TRUE, row.names = 2,
                      text=paste(csvlines[bands:conc],
                                 collapse="\n"))
# Replace the MW column with NA for most of the bands, and with
# the appropriate MW for the ladder bands.
geldata$MW <- NA
geldata["A1", "MW"] <- 100
geldata["A2", "MW"] <- 200
geldata["A3", "MW"] <- 300
geldata["A4", "MW"] <- 400
geldata["A5", "MW"] <- 500
geldata["A6", "MW"] <- 600
geldata["A7", "MW"] <- 700
geldata["A8", "MW"] <- 800
geldata["A9", "MW"] <- 900
geldata["A10", "MW"] <- 1000
geldata["B1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["B2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["B3", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["C1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["C2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["C3", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["D1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["D2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["D3", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["E1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["E2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["E3", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["F1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["F2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["F3", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["G1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["G2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["G3", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["H1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["H2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["H3", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["I1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["I2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["I3", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["J1", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["J2", "MW"] <- NA
geldata["J3", "MW"] <- NA

# Fit the data to a straight line, with a logarithmic scaling
# of the MW data.
mwmodel <- glm(MW~Rf, data=geldata, family=gaussian(link=log))

# Use the model to predict the molecular weights of the bands
# from other lanes. Include standard errors of the weights.
predict(mwmodel, newdata=subset(geldata, Lane.ID!="A"),
        type="response", se.fit=TRUE)
```

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

